<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 280, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 186, 907, 202]]<|/det|>
0625/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 208, 907, 223]]<|/det|>
May/June 2012  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 229, 907, 243]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 343, 235, 358]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 358, 601, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 373, 892, 403]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 415, 892, 445]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 445, 890, 461]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 473, 556, 490]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 503, 764, 535]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 631, 91]]<|/det|>
A cylindrical can is rolled along the ruler shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 98, 880, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 249, 320, 268]]<|/det|>
The can rolls over twice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 279, 594, 298]]<|/det|>
What is the circumference (distance all round) of the can?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 304, 133, 323]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 304, 489, 323]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 304, 636, 323]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 304, 660, 323]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 350, 92, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 350, 922, 384]]<|/det|>
Drops of water are dripping steadily from a tap (faucet). The diagram shows a measuring cylinder which has collected 120 drops of water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 390, 541, 520]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 755, 883, 775]]<|/det|>
How many drops in total will have been collected when the measuring cylinder reads \(10 \text{cm}^3?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 784, 175, 802]]<|/det|>

300

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 828, 96, 846]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 828, 742, 846]]<|/det|>
In a race, a car travels 60 times around a \(3.6\mathrm{km}\) track. This takes 2.4 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 858, 433, 876]]<|/det|>
What is the average speed of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 886, 133, 904]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 886, 230, 904]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 886, 298, 904]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 886, 390, 904]]<|/det|>
90 km/h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 886, 470, 904]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 886, 571, 904]]<|/det|>
144 km/h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 886, 737, 904]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 774, 91]]<|/det|> A metal block is heated until it is completely melted. It is then allowed to solidify. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 680, 121]]<|/det|> What happens to the mass of the metal during the changes of state? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 477, 277]]<|/det|>
mass during meltingmass during solidification
Adecreasesincreases
Bincreasesdecreases
Cincreasesstays constant
Dstays constantstays constant
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 304, 97, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 497, 322]]<|/det|> Two objects X and Y are placed on a balance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 335, 343, 352]]<|/det|> The balance tilts as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 361, 665, 445]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 458, 712, 477]]<|/det|> What does this show about the masses and weights of objects X and Y? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 488, 646, 617]]<|/det|>
massesweights
AX has less mass than YX has less weight than Y
BX has less mass than YX has more weight than Y
CX has the same mass as YX has less weight than Y
DX has the same mass as YX has more weight than Y
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 643, 96, 662]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 643, 562, 662]]<|/det|> A stone has a volume of \(0.50 \text{cm}^3\) and a mass of \(2.0 \text{g}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 674, 390, 692]]<|/det|> What is the density of the stone? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 702, 134, 720]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 702, 248, 720]]<|/det|> 0.25g/cm³ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 730, 133, 747]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 730, 237, 747]]<|/det|> 1.5g/cm³ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 756, 133, 774]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 756, 237, 774]]<|/det|> 2.5g/cm³ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 782, 133, 801]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 782, 237, 799]]<|/det|> 4.0g/cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 779, 92]]<|/det|>
Passengers are **not** allowed to stand on the upper deck of double-decker buses.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[314, 98, 678, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 244, 220, 263]]<|/det|>
Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 273, 134, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 273, 559, 292]]<|/det|>
They would cause the bus to become less stable.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 300, 131, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 300, 489, 317]]<|/det|>
They would cause the bus to slow down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 133, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 327, 567, 345]]<|/det|>
They would increase the kinetic energy of the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 352, 133, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 352, 549, 371]]<|/det|>
They would lower the centre of mass of the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 396, 96, 415]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 532, 415]]<|/det|>

a ball at rest on a bench

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 760, 96, 778]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 760, 603, 778]]<|/det|>
Electricity can be obtained from different energy resources.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 790, 841, 808]]<|/det|>
Which energy resource is used to obtain electricity without producing heat to boil water?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 818, 134, 836]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 819, 190, 836]]<|/det|>
coal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 846, 134, 864]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 846, 186, 864]]<|/det|>
gas

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 873, 134, 890]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 873, 262, 890]]<|/det|>
hydroelectric

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 898, 134, 917]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 898, 217, 915]]<|/det|>
nuclear

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 803, 106]]<|/det|>
A ball is dropped on to a hard surface and bounces. It does not bounce all the way but it started, so it has less gravitational potential energy than when it started.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[326, 109, 660, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 293, 405, 312]]<|/det|>
What happens to the 'lost' energy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 322, 134, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 322, 537, 342]]<|/det|>
It is converted into chemical and strain energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 348, 133, 366]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 348, 584, 367]]<|/det|>
It is converted into internal (heat) energy and sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 374, 131, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 374, 675, 393]]<|/det|>
It is destroyed as the ball rises upwards after hitting the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 400, 133, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 400, 517, 419]]<|/det|>
It is destroyed when the ball hits the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 444, 106, 463]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 400, 463]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 472, 133, 491]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 500, 133, 518]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 500, 334, 518]]<|/det|>
atmospheric pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 526, 133, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 526, 263, 545]]<|/det|>
liquid density

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 552, 133, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 552, 277, 571]]<|/det|>
liquid pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 596, 107, 615]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 596, 695, 615]]<|/det|>
In which position would a boy exert the most pressure on the ground?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 624, 133, 643]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 624, 292, 643]]<|/det|>
lying on his back

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 650, 133, 669]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 650, 255, 669]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 677, 133, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 677, 324, 695]]<|/det|>
standing on one foot

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 702, 133, 721]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 702, 322, 721]]<|/det|>
standing on two feet

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 823, 106]]<|/det|> On a warm day, a swimmer climbs out of a swimming pool into the open air and water from his skin. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 871, 152]]<|/det|> As the water evaporates, which molecules escape into the air first and what happens to average speed of the remaining water molecules? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 579, 308]]<|/det|>
first molecules to escapeaverage speed of the remaining molecules
Aleast energeticdecreases
Bleast energeticincreases
Cmost energeticdecreases
Dmost energeticincreases
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 335, 107, 352]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 621, 354]]<|/det|> Some air is trapped inside a metal can with a tightly fitting lid. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 361, 628, 560]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 571, 920, 604]]<|/det|> When the can is heated strongly behind a safety screen, the lid is blown off by the increased pressure inside the can. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 638, 634]]<|/det|> What causes the increase in pressure of the air inside the can? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 645, 134, 663]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 645, 569, 663]]<|/det|> The air molecules expand and take up more room. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 672, 134, 689]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 672, 467, 689]]<|/det|> The air molecules move more quickly. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 698, 134, 715]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 698, 574, 715]]<|/det|> The number of molecules inside the can increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 724, 134, 742]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 724, 571, 742]]<|/det|> The volume occupied by the molecules decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 769, 106, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 769, 514, 787]]<|/det|> A solid object has a very large thermal capacity. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 797, 304, 814]]<|/det|> What does this mean? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 825, 134, 842]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 825, 712, 842]]<|/det|> A large amount of energy is needed to make the object become hot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 852, 134, 870]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 852, 650, 870]]<|/det|> A large amount of energy is needed to make the object melt. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 878, 134, 896]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 878, 714, 896]]<|/det|> A small amount of energy is needed to make the object become hot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 904, 134, 922]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 904, 653, 922]]<|/det|> A small amount of energy is needed to make the object melt.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 107, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 609, 92]]<|/det|>
A hot drink is left in a room that is at a temperature of \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 103, 536, 123]]<|/det|>
What has happened to the drink after ten minutes?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 150]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 311, 150]]<|/det|>
Its density is lower.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 134, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 376, 175]]<|/det|>
Its internal energy is lower.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 134, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 425, 201]]<|/det|>
Its particles have equal energies.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 134, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 209, 415, 227]]<|/det|>
Its particles move more quickly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 253, 920, 288]]<|/det|>
An engineer wants to fix a steel washer on to a steel rod. The rod is just too big to fit into the hole of the washer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 295, 774, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 392, 536, 411]]<|/det|>
How can the engineer fit the washer on to the rod?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 420, 133, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 420, 479, 439]]<|/det|>
Cool the washer and put it over the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 448, 133, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 447, 771, 466]]<|/det|>
Cool the washer and rod to the same temperature and push them together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 475, 133, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 473, 495, 492]]<|/det|>
Heat the rod and then place it in the hole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 500, 133, 519]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 500, 541, 519]]<|/det|>
Heat the washer and then place it over the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 534, 92]]<|/det|> A rod is made of copper and wood joined together. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 100, 725, 242]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 256, 616, 276]]<|/det|> The rod is heated at the join in the centre for about a minute. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 288, 861, 307]]<|/det|> At which labelled point will the temperature be lowest, and at which point will it be highest? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 317, 433, 464]]<|/det|>
lowest temperaturehighest temperature
APQ
BPR
CSP
